title: Press selection list for Afghan newspapers 11 Nov 19
snippet:
Newspapers published in Kabul

Hasht-e Sobh (independent)
body:
1. Editorial entitled "Learn lesson from history" comments on the electoral watchdog groups' criticism of the Independent Election Commission for its decision to recount a number of votes unavailable in the biometric system. It says in addition to military issues, an electoral deadlock is also taking place in the country. It believes President Trump is not like his predecessor Barak Obama and will not intervene in the Afghan elections. (p 2, about 600 words in Dari, PROCESSING)

2. Report by Hasib Bahsh entitled "Electoral watchdog groups: Commission should give response to candidates' legitimate demands" (p 3, about 2,000 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Wahid Paiman entitled "Afghanistan, elections, and ethnic issues" calls on the people of Afghanistan to accept the reality that a competent presidential elections candidate regardless of which ethnic groups they belong to can be the next government. It says a genuine democracy has yet to be institutionalized in the country, but people feel that they have experienced a type of democracy after the fall of the Taliban regime. (p 6, about 1,800 words in Dari, NPP)

4. Article by Fardin Hazhir entitled "One address and two policies; injustice between Kabul University's daytime and nighttime sections" (p 4, about 1,200 words in Dari, NPP)

5. Article by Ferdaus Kawesh entitled "Crisis of our electoral democracy" says Abdullah Abdullah's recent remarks about the electoral process suggest that the crisis of the 2014 presidential polls will take place again. (p 4, about 1,800 words in Dari, NPP)

Mandegar (private)

1. Editorial entitled "What will Independent Election Commission do?" accuses the Independent Election Commission of reneging on its previous decisions, saying the commission ignores the request of the council of the presidential elections candidates that only biometrically-verified votes have validity and will have to be counted. It warns people will never participate in elections if the commission's new decision leads to any electoral crisis in the country. (p 2, about 900 words in Dari, EXCERPT 500 words)

2. Article by Ahmad Emran entitled "Amid electoral crisis" accuses the State-builder electoral ticket of perpetrating an organised fraud and of influencing the Independent Election Commission. It says the presidential office has launched a dangerous game in terms of elections, which it believes will harm all the achievements made in Afghanistan during the past 18 years. It quotes a number of observers as saying that the scenario of the 2014 presidential elections is taking place again. (p 2, about 1,600 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Mohammad Akram Andeshmand entitled "Look at Pakistan's policies towards Afghan peace process" believes Afghanistan and its people will achieve lasting peace in months if Pakistan stops supporting the Taliban and other insurgents operating in Afghanistan. It says Pakistan has always played a negative role in the Afghan peace process. (p 2, about 2,000 words in Dari, NPP)

Weesa (private)

1. Editorial entitled "Does Pakistan kill Pashtuns or bring them to power?" comments on the most recent US Congress report saying Pakistan has been trying to bring Pashtun ethnic group to power in Afghanistan and never wants any broad-based government there. It says it was Pakistan that helped the US invade Afghanistan and carry out deadly air strikes, calling on the Afghans to maintain national unity and not be haunted by such baseless propaganda. (p 2, about 500 words in Pashto, PROCESSING)

2. Article by Ali Musavi entitled "Suspension of recount of votes; sluggish work or breach of law?" comments on the Stability and Convergence electoral ticket's opposition to the Independent Election Commission's decision to launch the process of recount of votes in the provinces. It says the matter of concern is that there are serious differences between the Independent Election Commission and the Electoral Complaints Commission. (p 3, about 1,200 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Report by Bashir Ahmad Nadem entitled "Natural disasters and rainfall affect 70 per cent of pomegranate cultivated in Kandahar province" (p 3, about 1,800 words in Pashto, NPP)

4. Article by Amirzeb Kamawal entitled "Afghanistan's history distorted in Indian movies" (p 4, about 1,200 words in Pashto, NPP)

5. Article by Faiz Mohammad Faiz entitled "Fate of elections and responsibility of Independent Election Commission" holds the Independent Election Commission accountable for the current ambiguities in the election process, saying the commission has a duty to stop every type of illegal interference in its work. It describes foreign interference as a big factor behind tensions in the election process, calling on the government to defend the commission's legal and legitimate moves. (pp 1, 4, about 2,000 words in Pashto, NPP)

6. Article by Strategic Centre for Regional Studies entitled "Death of leader of Islamic State group and its global consequences" (pp 2, 4, about 2,000 words in Dari, NPP)

Arman-e Melli (close to the National Union of Journalists of Afghanistan)

1. Editorial entitled "Another intrigue" describes Afghanistan's history as gloomy and painful, saying brothers have killed each other for power on many occasions. It says the Afghans have the right to be concerned about existing tensions in the election process, and warns the process of recount of votes in the provinces will make it difficult to announce the primary election result in the coming days. (p 2, about 500 words in Dari, NPP)

2. Article by Noorullah Walizada entitled "Step towards crisis every day; who is culprit?" warns the likelihood of a serious electoral crisis in Afghanistan is very high nowadays, and calls for preventing any possible crisis. It holds the State-builder electoral ticket headed by President Ghani accountable for existing tensions in the election process, saying Abdullah Abdullah's political allies will not demonstrate any flexibility if the State-builder electoral ticket perpetrates fraud. (p 3, about 1,500 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Report entitled "Dr Abdullah: Recount of votes should be stopped; Amdullah Saleh: Do not make pretexts" (pp 1, 7, about 700 words in Dari, NPP)

The Daily Afghanistan (private)

1. Editorial by Mohammad Hedayat entitled "Generation of crisis cannot be in interests of anyone" says yesterday's remarks by Abdullah Abdullah - head of the Stability and Convergence electoral ticket - suggest that his team is not in favour of crisis. It urges heads of all the electoral tickets to take the country's current sensitive situation into account and avoid taking any action that fuels hatred among ordinary people. (p 2, about 900 words in Dari, PROCESSING)

2. Article by Abdul Qayum Ayati entitled "Preconditions of lasting peace in Afghanistan" believes the only way to establish lasting peace in Afghanistan is to ensure national interests, identify foes and friends, and curtail foreigners' hands from the prolongation and spread of insecurity. It stresses that the peace process should be managed and led by the central government, saying the armed opponents should also declare a ceasefire and renounce violence so that direct peace talks will be facilitated. (p 3, about 1,000 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Mohammad Salim Naji entitled "Role of political culture in institutionalization and elimination of democracy in country" (p 3, about 1,800 words in Dari, NPP)

Eslah (state-run)

1. Editorial entitled "Electoral crisis should be prevented" discusses the Independent Election Commission's decision to launch the process of recount of votes in the provinces, calling on the electoral tickets to cooperate with the commission instead of opposing it. It says public opinion and the media now feel that another electoral crisis is going to happen in the coming days, calling no those involved in election-related affairs to join hands and prevent any possible electoral crisis. (pp 1, 5, about 900 words in Dari, NPP)

2. Article by Payenda entitled "Process of fight against illicit drugs needs collective efforts" comments on the most recent SIGAR report on the cultivation and production of illicit drugs in Afghanistan. It says the Afghan government believes there is a direct link between narcotics and insecurity and that the Taliban meet part of their military and financial needs by smuggling drugs. It calls on the international community to cooperate with Afghanistan to eliminate narcotics so that insurgents will be unable to prolong the war. (p 3, about 1,200 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Asif Muhajir entitled "Condition of political parties in country; opportunities and challenges" accuses a majority of Afghan prominent political personalities and former jihadi leaders of choosing personal over national interests, saying differences and confrontations between the central government and political parties have made the peace process complicated. (p 4, about 900 words in Dari, NPP)

4. Article by Enabi entitled "Government's peace proposal makes peace process move in right direction" discusses the nine rounds of peace talks between US special envoy for Afghanistan reconciliation Zalmay Khalilzad and Taliban representatives in Doha, Qatar. It believes establishing peace and ending the current war in Afghanistan will be highly possible if the Afghan government's new peace proposal is put into practice. (p 2, about 1,600 words in Dari, NPP)

5. Report entitled "Upper house of parliament reacts to Taliban stance on China meeting; do not make pretexts in peace process" (p 2, about 400 words in Dari, NPP)

Etilaat-e Roz (private)

1. Editorial entitled "Do not politicise election process" says although three electoral tickets have boycotted the process of recount of votes in the provinces, the Independent Election Commission continues to recount votes there. It warns the election process is being politicised which it says will adversely impact the credibility of the commission. It stresses that the primary election result should be announced in the next three days, but now it seems that it will not take place. (pp 1, 2, about 800 words in Dari, NPP)

Hewad (state-run)

1. Editorial entitled "Democracy will never be sacrificed for certain individuals' demands" calls on the Independent Election Commission to announce the primary election result on the scheduled date in spite of objections by a number of individuals and groups. It says no electoral ticket has the right to interfere in the work of the election commissions, adding that boycotting by certain electoral tickets of the process of recount of votes cannot be justifiable and acceptable. (p 2, about 650 words in Pashto, PROCESSING)

2. Report entitled "Independent Election Commission: Our work is legal; electoral tickets should cooperate with us" quotes top members of the Independent Election Commission as saying that they will continue to abide by the law. They urge heads and other senior members of all the electoral tickets to cooperate with them to ensure further transparency in the vote counting process. (p 8, about 1,000 words in Pashto, NPP)

Maseer (private)

1. Editorial entitled "UN needs to play active role to settle electoral tensions" discusses presidential elections candidate Abdullah Abdullah's opposition to the Independent Election Commission's decision to recount the votes in the provinces before separating genuine from fake votes. It urges the UN to interfere in case tensions among the electoral tickets loom larger, calling on the candidates to accept any decision made by the UN. (p 2, about 600 words in Pashto, PROCESSING)

2. Unattributed article entitled "Fate of elections; Abdullah Abdullah says he does not accept election result; President Ghani will be held accountable for crisis" (p 3, about 800 words in Pashto, NPP)

Sarkhat (private)

1. Editorial entitled "Abdullah is not committed to democracy" accuses Abdullah Abdullah of breaching the law by opposing the Independent Election Commission's decision to recount the votes in the provinces. It says Abdullah's recent remarks on the election process suggest that he has realised his defeat in the polls and this is why he is trying to conceal his defeat by levelling accusations against the commission and electoral tickets. (p 2, about 600 words in Pashto, PROCESSING)

2. Unattributed article entitled "Controversial presidential polls; prolongation of this process will impact people's hopes and expectations from democracy" lashes out at the Independent Election Commission for its failure to announce the primary election result, saying people's lost trust in elections has yet to be restored. (p 2, about 800 words in Pashto, NPP)

3. Article by Dawa Khan Minapal entitled "Ministry of Foreign Affairs needs to be reformed fundamentally" says there is no doubt that the National Unity Government made a lot of achievements and managed to ensure transparency in the process of collecting national incomes. It gives an assurance that President Ghani will thoroughly assess the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to address existing shortcomings in the process of making appointments to it. (p 3, about 1,200 words in Pashto, NPP)

Shahadat (affiliated with Hekmatyar-led Hezb-e Islami)

1. Editorial entitled "Disputes, differences within Ministry of Foreign Affairs" says the people of Afghanistan have been the main victims of inappropriate policies and confrontations among top government officials during the past 18 years. It warns differences within the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will loom larger which it says will prove costly and dangerous for ordinary people only. (p 2, about 700 words in Dari, NPP)

2. Unattributed article entitled "Harassment, bullying in Afghanistan's official and unofficial places" (p 2, about 1,000 words in Pashto, NPP)

3. Report entitled "Office of chief executive: Intra-Afghan meeting in China to be held in next two weeks" (p 1, about 200 words in Pashto, NPP)

Newspapers published in Kandahar

Tolo-e Afghan (state-run) 5 November

1. Report entitled "Several provincial governors hold video conference with minister of mines and petroleum to inform him of current projects in their provinces" (pp 1, 4, about 900 words in Pashto, NPP)

2. Report entitled "President Ghani meets with German minister of development, welcomes Germany's contribution to Afghanistan's development" (pp 1, 4, about 700 words in Pashto, NPP)

3. Report entitled "Ceremony held in Kandahar to mark international day of journalists' immunity" (pp 1, 4, about 800 words in Pashto, NPP)

4. Editorial entitled "Journalists have the right to be protected" urges the central government and other relevant bodies to take action to ensure security of reporters and other media officials serving in Afghanistan. It calls for taking action against the powerful individuals who perpetrate violence against reporters and stop them from gathering reports. (p 2 765 words in Pashto, NPP)

Totobay weekly (private) 3 November

1. Report entitled "Governor of eastern Konar province says large-scale military operations underway to root out Islamic State militants in province" (pp 1, 4, about 350 words in Dari, NPP)

2. Report entitled "Pakistan continues to fire rockets from across the Durand Line" accuses Pakistani of training, nurturing, harbouring, equipping terrorists on its territory. (pp 1,3 1035 words in Pashto, NPP)

3. Report entitled "Khalilzad concludes his Pakistan visit to discuss Afghan peace with top Pakistani officials" (pp 1, 3, about 400 words in Pashto, NPP)

4. Report entitled "Salam Mobile Network Operator connected to real time" says the move will help ensure speed and transparency in the revenue collection process. (pp 1, 3, about 700 words in Pashto, NPP)

5. Report entitled "Pro-peace gathering calls for increase in role of women in the peace process" (pp 1, 2, about 750 words in Pashto, NPP)

6. Editorial entitled "What does Baghdadi's death mean for Afghanistan?" gives an assurance that the death of supreme Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi will prove dangerous for his ordinary loyalists in Afghanistan. It says the militant group will be further crushed in the country. (p 2, about 700 words in Pashto, NPP)

7. Report entitled "Fazel Rehman's serious warning again Imran Khan" says political tensions in Pakistan are looming larger with the passing of every day as prominent cleric and politician Maulana Fazel Rahman demands Prime Minister Imran Khan's dismissal. (p 10, about 650 words in Pashto, NPP)

Tolo-e Afghan (state-run) 2 Nov

1. Report entitled "Kandahar governor says his administration is determined to tackle challenges against implementation of major projects in province" says Kandahar provincial governor Hayatullah Hayat has highlighted the importance and significance of key projects in the province. (pp 1, 4, about 800 words in Pashto, NPP)

2. Report entitled "Ministry of Finance briefs President Ghani about its achievements and activities" says the acting minister of finance minister and his team presented a detailed report on their recent achievements and activities to the president. (pp 1, 4, about 800 words in Pashto, NPP)

3. Report entitled "Deputy provincial governor of Kandahar highlights local administration's plans to improve agriculture in province". (pp 1, 4, about 500 words in Pashto, NPP)

4. Unattributed article entitled "Sports guard society against evils" highlights the importance and promotion of sports among young people in Afghanistan. It says a vast majority of the Afghans are suffering from mental issues due to different problems and this is why they need to do physical exercise regularly. (p 2, about 700 words in Pashto, NPP)

Source: As listed

Source: Afghan press selection list in Dari and Pashto 11 Nov 19
